review_title: This is a Non For Profit, working for NYC most in need
job_title: Program Manager in New York, NY
pros: Generous paid holidays, vacation and benefits plan. Friendly co-workers, helpful and caring staff at all levels of the organization. Best part your getting paid to help others and improve peoples lives.
cons: As a non for profit salaries are low and you deal with some incompetence.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The mission is great, that's basically it.
cons:
Where do I even start? In my 15 years of work experience, this is without a doubt, the most toxic workplace I have ever seen. Do you love being yelled at and called stupid? This is the place for you! Are you the type to stay at work until late at night without even accomplishing anything? You'll get a promotion here right away! Do you enjoy getting text messages and phone calls from your boss during the weekends because something *urgent* needs to be done? You'll fit right in! 

Seriously folks, please save yourself from the trauma. I have been here for almost a year and have witnessed turnovers like crazy. Read the negative reviews, they're all accurate. The only ones who have longevity here are: 1. those who can suck up the bosses 2. the old-timers who are just waiting for retirement 3. thick-skinned folks who have lost all their ambitions in life.

review_title: You are doing good work, and way too much of it.
job_title: Case Manager in New York, NY
pros:
Base pay is fair. 
Colleagues often share ideals about non-profit work and importance.
People served are incredible and will make a mark on your life.
cons: Administration at every level is corrupt, they value an employee who does the work of 3 employees and shuts their mouth. If you suggest ideas that could help streamline work and save money/time, it will most likely be poached and you won't be given credit. If you ask them to hire people to replace the ones that quit, they label you a complainer. They will tell you this is how non-profit works. I will tell you they make double your pay to tell you to be quiet and risk patient satisfaction/success for cutting budgets.

review_title: Growing organization with employees who truly care

pros: My supervisors were absolutely amazing and supportive. HR office was modern and up to date with technology. CEO truly cares. Many events to celebrate staff and clients.

review_title: A great place to work if you prefer dysfunctional leadership and intense micromanagement.
job_title: Director in New York, NY
pros: Quality programs, overall a good mission, decent benefits.
cons:
CEO and upper management do not connect well with a lot of the rank-and-file employees. Although they try from time to time, it comes off as a bit contrived. Many in the C-suite micromanage, which leaves employees questioning their self-worth or why they are even there to begin with. The CEO has special relationships with long-time staff, but barely says anything beyond hello to other staff members.

Anything that is written -- either in development or communications -- has to pass through a gauntlet of written word experts, which adds more time to the process and only adds pressure to those expected to execute the task. Everyone has to have a say. 

Others in the C-suite do not like it when you reach out to their staff without their knowledge; you have to get their permission before emailing their staff. Another C-suite member has to review every email written by her staff. In fact, she micromanage her staff so much they eventually have no choice but to leave. One other annoying habit of hers: if you are in a conversation with her, and the CEO calls or walks by, she'll drop you like a hot potato and run after the CEO because she's so desperate for mommy's attention. There has been a lot of turnover in her department, and it's not difficult to understand why.

Other highlights: many staff in the corporate office only care about themselves; emails go unanswered for days; the finance department is a headache to work with; and the HR department can best be described as a waste of space.

As if all of this were not enough to scare away talented employees, members of the C-suite tend to greet each other in the mornings with a kiss on the lips (prior to COVID of course), which was especially weird and inappropriate.

job_title: Direct Care Worker in Brooklyn, NY

Justice Department was always involved.  Worst companies to work for. Cheated employees out of pay. Pocket the money for themselves.  Too much favoritism. No respect.
